entry.title: The Brown review of the rail franchising programme
entry.summary: Richard Brown’s review of the rail franchising programme.
entry.content:
Following the cancellation of the competition to run the InterCity West Coast franchise, the Secretary of State asked Richard Brown, Chairman of Eurostar, to carry out an urgent assessment of the implications of the flaws in the West Coast procurement for the rest of the rail franchising programme.

In his independent report, Mr Brown makes a number of recommendations for the future of the rail franchising programme.

Related documents

  • Government’s rail strategy receives independent endorsement press notice, 10 January 2010
  • Rail franchising written statement by the Secretary of State for Transport, 10 January 2013
  • Response to the report of the Laidlaw inquiry
  • Report of the Laidlaw inquiry
  • Letter from the Secretary of State to Richard Brown, 15 October 2012
  • West Coast Main Line franchise competition cancelled press notice, 3 October 2012
  • West Coast Main Line and franchising oral statement by the Secretary of State for Transport, 29 October 2012

entry.title: Guidance on the pre-application process for major infrastructure projects
entry.summary: This guidance sets out the requirements and procedures for the pre-application process and consultation for major infrastructure projects.
entry.content:
This document is the result of merging and expanding reworked versions of the local authority guidance and the pre-application guidance that went out to consultation on 13 April 2012. By merging these, we are avoiding unnecessary repetition of the description of common processes.

The new guidance sets out the necessary requirements and procedures and gives clarity on the scope and scale of the consultation required at the pre-application stage. It covers all the main processes required by an applicant prior to the submission of an application, including the pre-application consultation, Environmental Impact Assessment, Habitats Regulations Assessments, and advice on drafting a Development Consent Order.

entry.title: Reliability of journeys on the Highways Agency’s motorway and A road network
entry.summary: Impact indicator, disaggregated by junction, published monthly from May 2011.
entry.content:
DfT Business plan impact indicator

  • Geographical coverage: England
  • Information broken down by: national level aggregation

Latest data

  • Provisional data show that 81.9% of journeys made on Highways Agency managed roads between December 2011 and November 2012 were ‘on time’. This is 0.4 percentage points lower than the previous rolling year, ending in October 2012.
  • During November 2012, provisional data show that 76.6% of journeys on Highways Agency’s motorway and ‘A’ road network were ‘on time’. This is 4.7 percentage points lower than the equivalent figure for November 2011.
  • The annual reliability measure consistently increased up to March 2012, but has fallen in the last eight months, and is now at a similar level to that observed in mid-2011. 2012 was the second wettest year since records began with substantial rainfall during the final three quarters of the year. Significant amounts of rainfall compared to 2011 will have led to slower speeds on the network, slower journeys and thus a fall in reliability.

Click here to view this data in an interactive chart

Percentage of journeys on Highways Agency motorways and A roads deemed ‘on time’: monthly from June 2012

Percentage of journeys ‘on time’

  Year ending Month Year ending percentage points change
June 2012 83.3 82.3 -0.2
July 2012 83.0 81.8 -0.2
August 2012 82.9 81.9 -0.1
September 2012 82.6 80.5 -0.3
October 2012 82.3 79.6 -0.3
November 2012P 81.9 76.6 -0.4

Source: Highways Agency Traffic Information System (HATRIS) Database

P = provisional

Background information

This indicator monitors the reliability of journeys made on Highways Agency’s motorway and A road network.

The indicator is measured by the percentage of ‘journeys’ on these roads that are ‘on time’. For this measure:

  • a ‘journey’ represents travel between adjacent junctions on the network
  • an ‘on time journey’ is defined as one which is completed within a set reference time, drawn from historic data on that particular section of road
  • reference journey times are updated for the April data each year - further information on the impact of updating reference times can be found in section 3 of the latest statistical release

At present, information about the reliability of journeys on individual routes, or between particular junctions on the network, are not sufficiently robust to be presented as official statistics. This is due to the range of different sources used to calculate journey times across the network.

The Department has been working with the Highways Agency to address these issues of comparability. As a result we will be making a number of methodological changes to improve the quality of the reliability measure from the publication of the January 2013 statistics (in March). More detail on these changes will be provided in updated technical guidance.

Journey time reliability data for individual road sections is currently published by the Highways Agency through the data.gov.uk webpage.

  • publishing schedule: monthly
  • last updated: 10 January 2013
  • next update: 14 February 2013

Other related data and information

  • Reliability of journeys on Highways Agency’s motorway and ‘A’ road network: November 2012 - statistical release page
  • An introduction into the Department for Transport’s congestion statistics
  • Methodology for calculation of reliability on Highways Agency’s motorway and ‘A’ road network

Further information

  • Business Plan 2012-2015
  • Input and impact indicators
  • For further information on this impact indicator, please contact: jay.symonds@dft.gsi.gov.uk

entry.title: Reliability of journeys on the Highway's Agencys motorway and A road network: November 2012
entry.summary: This Statistical Release presents information about the reliability of journeys on motorways and ‘A’ roads managed by the Highways Agency during November 2012.
entry.content:
Key points

  • In the year ending November 2012, provisional data show that 81.9% of journeys on the Highways Agency managed network were ‘on time’. This is 0.4 percentage points lower than the previous year, ending October 2012..
  • Provisional data show that 76.6% of journeys on the Highways Agency network during November 2012 were ‘on time’, down 4.7 percentage points from November 2011.

Technical information

  • Information on Road congestion and reliability statistics, including the pre-release access list and related technical documentation can be found here.

Contact us

  • congestion.stats@dft.gsi.gov.uk
  • Phone: 020 7944 6579

entry.title: Stopping up and diversion orders: reform of the application process for local highways
entry.summary: This consultation details proposals to simplify the process of applying for the stopping up and diversion of a highway.
entry.content:
Summary

Following the ‘Penfold review’, this consultation details proposals to simplify the process of applying for the stopping up and diversion of a highway where this is required for the purpose of property development.

We propose to permit applications for a stopping-up or diversion order to be submitted at the same time as applying for planning permission for the proposed development (whereas under the existing legislation the developer can only apply after securing planning permission), and options for devolving decision-making to the local authority level.

Related documents

  • Implementation of the Penfold review, written statement by the Parliamentary Under Secretary of State for Transport, 9 January 2013
  • Implementation of the Penfold review, written statement by the Parliamentary Under Secretary of State for Transport, 18 September 2012
  • Implementation of the Penfold review, written statement by the Secretary of State for Transport, 16 July 2012

entry.title: Building materials and components statistics: December 2012
entry.summary: Statistics and analysis on the construction sector
entry.content:
Presents information on selected building materials, including monthly data on price indices, bricks, cement and concrete blocks. It also presents quarterly data on sand and gravel, slate, concrete roofing tiles, ready-mixed concrete and imports and exports of construction products.

entry.title: Luton Borough Council's compulsory purchase order for Station House: inspector's report
entry.summary: Report by the inspector who held an inquiry into the Luton Borough Council (Station House, Midland Road) compulsory purchase order 2011.
entry.content:
This report was written by the inspector who held an inquiry into the Luton Borough Council (Station House, Midland Road) compulsory purchase order 2011. It contains recommendations to amend words in the order and then confirm it.

Related documents

  • Luton Borough Council’s compulsory purchase order for Station House: decision letter

entry.title: Luton Borough Council's compulsory purchase order for Station House: decision letter
entry.summary: Explaining the Secretary of State's decision about the Luton Borough Council (Station House, Midland Road) compulsory purchase order 2011.
entry.content:
This letter gives details about the Secretary of State’s decision on the Luton Borough Council (Station House, Midland Road) compulsory purchase order 2011. It explains that the Secretary of State has decided to confirm the order subject to a specified modification.

Related documents

  • Luton Borough Council’s compulsory purchase order for Station House: inspector’s report

entry.title: BIS workforce management: November 2012
entry.summary: Management information on staff numbers and paybill costs in BIS, its agencies and executive non-departmental public bodies
entry.content:
For workforce numbers, both payroll and non-payroll (contingent labour, including consultants) information is provided, split between full-time equivalents (FTE) and headcount, with payroll staff numbers mapped to standard Civil Service grades.

For costs, payroll paybill information is broken down into its component parts ie salaries, allowances, employers pensions contributions etc. For non-payroll costs, these are split between costs for consultancy and those of other non-payroll workers.

Covers November of the financial year 2012 to 2013.

For costs, payroll paybill information is broken down into its component parts i.e. salaries, allowances, employers pensions contributions etc. For non-payroll costs, these are split between costs for consultancy and those of other non-payroll workers.

Covers April to November of the financial year 2012 to 2013.

entry.title: Department for Transport equality monitoring
entry.summary: Summary of findings on equalities in employment at the Department for Transport.
entry.content:
These reports feature an analysis of staff diversity, for staff in post between 1 April 2011 and 31 March 2012. The analysis looks at staff in post, cessations, grievances and discipline, training, sickness absence, performance markings and recruitment, and considers whether there were significant differences with respect to sex, race, disability, pay band, age, sexual orientation, religion and belief and working pattern.

Equality monitoring in the transport agencies

  • Highways Agency (HA) equality monitoring 2011 to 2012
  • Driving Standards Agency (DSA) equality monitoring 2011 to 2012
  • Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) equality monitoring 2011 to 2012
  • Vehicle Certification Agency (VCA) equality monitoring 2011 to 2012
  • Marine and Coastguard Agency (MCA) equality monitoring 2011 to 2012
  • Vehicle and Operator Services Agency (VOSA) equality monitoring 2011 to 2012

entry.title: Export control training bulletin 9: January 2013
entry.summary: Courses, seminars and workshops from the Export Control Organisation to enhance your understanding of the UK's strategic export controls.
entry.content:
Courses, seminars and workshops from the Export Control Organisation to enhance your understanding of the UK’s strategic export controls.

Events are aimed at exporting and trading individuals or companies of all sizes, as well as government organisations, and cater for a wide range of knowledge levels.

Includes all details, charges and an application form.

entry.title: Equality monitoring in DSA 2011 to 2012
entry.summary: An analysis of staff diversity in DSA, for staff in post between 1 April 2011 and 31 March 2012.
entry.content:
An analysis of staff diversity, for staff in post between 1 April 2011 and 31 March 2012.

The analysis looks at:

  • staff in post
  • cessations
  • grievances and discipline
  • training
  • sickness absence
  • performance marking
  • recruitment

It considers whether there were significant differences with respect to:

  • sex
  • race
  • disability
  • pay band
  • age
  • sexual orientation
  • religion and belief
  • working pattern
